I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the formulation of the country strategy and program for Viet Nam (2007–2010),1 
the Government of Viet Nam (the Government) requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
technical  assistance  (TA)  to  prepare  the  Quality  and  Safety  Improvement  of  Agricultural 
Products Project.2 ADB’s TA Fact-Finding Mission visited Viet Nam in December 2006 and 
reached understanding with the Government on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA. The TA is 
included in ADB’s 2007 assistance program for Viet Nam. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  Government’s  long-term  strategy  for  poverty  reduction  was  elaborated  in  its 
Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS) announced in May 2002.The 
CPRGS emphasized the importance of agriculture and rural development in reducing rural 
poverty  and  contributing  to  sustainable  and  equitable  economic  growth.  CPRGS’  strategic 
thrusts are now reflected in the 5-year Socio-Economic Development Plan (SEDP: 2006–2010) 
launched in June 2006. SEDP is also the country’s current poverty reduction strategy and aims 
to (i) accelerate sustainable economic growth and development; (ii) improve people’s material, 
cultural, and spiritual life; (iii) create the foundations to boost industrialization and modernization 
and to gradually develop a knowledge-based economy; and (iv) improve the country’s regional 
and global status. SEDP particularly emphasizes the importance of business development in 
achieving sustainable growth, and the need for increased competitiveness of agricultural and 
agro-based products with improved product quality and food safety. 
 
3.  The agriculture sector in Viet Nam demonstrated rapid growth averaging about 4% per 
annum during the last decade. Food security has improved at the national level and the country 
has turned from a net food importer into one of the world’s major exporters of a number of 
agricultural products. The sector’s growth was largely supported by the market-oriented policy 
and institutional reforms initiated in the late 1980s, and by increased investment in irrigation and 
other  inputs.  However,  continued  agricultural  growth  will  require  both  diversified  farming 
systems  appropriate  for  varied  agro-ecological  conditions,  and  more  locally  driven 
improvements in productivity, value, and quality of agricultural production. To address this issue 
in the medium term, the Government aims to (i) promote production and processing of high-
value products; (ii) improve agricultural research, extension, and market information services; (iii) 
intensify efforts to ensure better product quality and food safety based on sound agricultural 
practices; and (iv)  promote agribusiness and agro-based enterprises. 
 
4.  In the country’s upland areas, commercial crop production has shown rapid growth with 
improved  access  to  domestic  and  international  markets.  Due  to  increased  commercial 
production, high average annual growth rates in the recent 5 years have been recorded for  
vegetables (3.7%), tea (8.9%), coffee (8.5%), and fruits (7.9%). Dynamic entrepreneurship of 
Vietnamese farmers contributed to such high growth rates and led to the expansion of rural 
business households, and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Increased efforts for 
promoting commercial values in the supply chains of these agricultural products are urgently 
required  and  must  be  based  on  improved  access  to  advanced  technology  in  production, 
postharvest operations, and marketing.

5.  Quality  and  Safety  Improvements  in  Agricultural  Products.  As  Viet  Nam’s 
agricultural sector becomes increasingly integrated with domestic and international markets, 
improvements in product quality and food safety assume greater importance, with key concerns 
being meat hygiene (as high as 77% of pigmeat3 infected by salmonella and the average 
incidence of diarrhea is 1.5 cases per person per year), and pesticide residues with more than 
10% of all vegetables sold having residues higher than national standards, while antibiotic 
residues4 in  meat  is  also  a  major  concern.  The  country’s  accession  to  the  World  Trade 
Organization in November 2006 accelerated the implementation of the Government’s action 
programs for strengthening the relevant legal and regulatory frameworks for food safety. The 
Government also recognizes that to date, most of the extension effort has been directed at 
increasing  on-farm  productivity  by  increasing  inputs 5  made  possible  by  improved  rural 
infrastructure (improved access). The impacts from such changes have only recently attracted 
international attention. The Government recognizes that this must be addressed throughout the 
length of the marketing chain as food quality is only as good as its weakest point. Efforts need 
to  be  directed  at  agricultural  research,  extension,  marketing,  postharvest  operations,  and 
product grading and certification. However, financial and human resources in the public sector 
prevent the establishment of an effective regulatory mechanism, and scarce resources are often 
scattered. Close coordination among related activities is essential.6 
 
6.  Efficient Value Chains for Agricultural Products. In Viet Nam, agricultural marketing 
activities remain largely local, and linkages between producers, traders, and consumers are not 
well developed. With small scale production still dominating rural industries, the challenge of 
product aggregation continues to threaten food quality as marketing chains tend to be extended 
with many commercial entities along its length. Contractual arrangements between producers 
and  processors  are  rare  though  increasing  in  certain  commodities  such  as  cashew  nuts, 
peanuts, tobacco and sugar cane in the central and south central regions. The role of the state 
in  promoting  closer  linkages  is  being  achieved  through  SOE  factories  processing  primary 
produce but is limited to commercial interests of the processors. Efforts to introduce safety 
standards and confirm the hygiene status need to be encouraged to generate increased value 
added from various commodity and product supply chains but starting at the producer. Any 
delay in addressing food safety and SPS problems is likely to adversely impact on  export 
competitiveness.   
 
7.  Strengthened Producers and Private SMEs. Continued reforms in the Government’s 
policies and institutions are also required in line with the shift of focus to commercial production 
and marketing of agricultural and agro-based products other than rice in which Viet Nam has 
succeeded in becoming a major player in the international market. Production and marketing of 
diversified crops outside SOEs need to be further promoted. While significant private SME 
processing of agricultural and aquaculture produce is already evident, the legal and regulatory 
environment is also being addressed by ADB,7 There remains a need for medium to long-term 
funds to assist private SMEs in diversifying their production, marketing, and processing activities 
that should incorporate appropriate postharvest handling operations. SME growth is expected to

8.  ADB has provided loan and TA projects in agriculture to support the Government’s 
critical policy and institutional reform measures for market-oriented growth and to increase 
agricultural productivity through improved research, extension, and market information systems. 
These operations are being satisfactorily implemented, and the Government is highly committed 
to pursuing the reforms for market liberalization and achieving a smooth transition from the 
production  system  based  on  centralized  planning  to  production  and  marketing  initiated  by 
individual  farmers  and  private  traders.  ADB  also  provided  TA,  in  collaboration  with  the 
Department  for  International  Development  of  the  United  Kingdom,  to  undertake  analytical 
research work on operational and policy issues linked to market development for pro-poor 
development outcomes, and help build local capacity for undertaking policy-oriented research.8 
Considering sector knowledge and the relevant lessons and experiences accumulated through 
these operations, ADB will continue to support Government efforts in the sector, with increased 
focus on producing and marketing agricultural and agro-based products with better quality and 
assured safety. 
 
9.  In view of the foregoing, the project for improving the quality and safety of agricultural 
products will support the Government’s new SEDP for agriculture and rural development in line 
with ADB’s new country strategy and program for Viet Nam, by promoting a business-led, pro-
poor, and sustainable economic growth with emphasis on private agro-based SMEs. The project 
design will be consistent with and complement the ongoing and planned projects of ADB and 
other external funding agencies. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA aims to assist the Government in formulating a detailed investment proposal to 
improve  the  quality  and  safety  of  agricultural  and  agro-based  products.  It  will  ultimately 
contribute  to  the  country’s  sustainable,  pro-poor  agricultural  growth  by  increasing  the 
competitiveness  of  agricultural  and  agro-based  products  and  improving  linkages  among 
stakeholders  (producers,  traders,  product  processors,  and  consumers).  It  will  increase 
commodity  and  product  values  along  their  supply  chains,  and  strengthen  the  capacity  of 
relevant institutions. The expected outcome of the ensuing project includes (i) improved quality 
and safety standards of agricultural and agro-based products; (ii) increased number of viable 
SMEs in agriculture and agro-industry; and (iii) strengthened capacity and improved awareness 
of central and local-level government institutions, farmers, and private enterprises. The design 
and monitoring framework for the TA is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA activities will be implemented in two phases: analytical sector reviews, and 
project design and consensus building. During the first phase, the TA will (i) assess the overall 
economy and rural development contexts in Viet Nam; (ii) assess the agriculture sector and 
SME  lending  operations,  including  the  policies  and  strategies  of  the  Government,  and 
availability of and gaps in funds for SMEs; (iii) analyze the current status relating to quality and 
safety of agricultural and agro-based products, including opportunities, issues, and regulatory 
                                                 
8  ADB. 2003. Proposed Technical Assistance for Making Markets Work Better for the Poor. Manila (TA 6113-REG).

and institutional frameworks; (iv) examine the potentials of and constraints to sustainable crop 
development and agribusiness development; (v) examine the current situation and activities of 
various stakeholders along the supply chains of the selected priority crops and processed 
products,  including  seed  production,  producers’  farming  systems,  capacity  of  processing 
facilities, and domestic and international market situations and marketing channels; (vi) review 
performance and important lessons from past and ongoing projects of ADB and other external 
funding agencies; and (vii) formulate sector and subsector road maps to present medium- to 
long-term initiatives and visions for the sustainable and equitable growth of the agriculture 
sector.  
 
12.  On  the basis of the outcome of the first phase, the TA will (i) examine, evaluate, and 
make recommendations on alternative investment options to improve the quality and safety of 
agricultural and agro-based products, and increase product competitiveness; (ii) examine the 
performance  and  capacity  of  the  relevant  institutions  and  staff  involved  in  agribusiness 
development, postharvest research, extension, and market information services at central and 
local levels; (iii) identify priority crops and potential project provinces with the use of appropriate 
criteria and in consultation with the Government and ADB; (iv) prepare a detailed investment 
project  proposal  that  can  be  considered  for  possible  ADB  financing,  with  appropriate 
implementation and funding arrangements; (v) help prepare the Government's feasibility studies 
for the project proposal; (vi) assess institutional, environmental, public health, and social risks, 
and formulate measures to ensure adequate safeguards; (vii) estimate financial and economic 
costs and benefits of the project proposal; and (viii) assess the impact of the proposed project 
on  the  agriculture  sector,  agricultural  production  and  productivity,  employment,  external 
earnings, role of women, livelihood of ethnic minority groups, environment, and public health. 
 
13.  The TA will help formulate consensus on the proposed project design and on necessary 
policy and institutional measures for effective implementation by involving a wide range of key 
stakeholders at critical milestones of the TA. The TA outputs will be regularly discussed among 
key  stakeholders,  including  relevant  government  agencies,  provincial  governments,  farmer 
groups,  universities,  private  enterprises,  external  funding  agencies,  and  civil  society 
organizations. Consultative workshops and seminars will be organized in different regions and 
selected provinces in the country to obtain appropriate feedback and disseminate TA findings.  
 
14.  A  detailed  project  proposal  for  an  ensuing  loan  project  will  be  formulated  at  TA 
completion. The project scope is expected to include (i) strengthening  support services in 
agriculture; (ii) assisting agribusiness households and enterprise development; (iii) improving 
relevant  sector  policies,  institutions,  and  infrastructure;  (iv)  strengthening  public-private 
partnership  in  selected  commercial  crops;  and  (v)  strengthening  local-level  capacity  to 
implement  the  decentralization  policy  of  the  Government,  and  to  improve  technology  and 
delivery of market information services. The project is expected to have a positive impact on 
poverty reduction among the poor. Special attention will be given to specific social issues 
related  to  gender  and  ethnic  minority  groups.  An  initial  poverty  and  social  analysis  is  in 
Appendix 2. Another positive impact will be the reduction of public health and environmental 
risks through improved practices in crop production, pest management, and product processing. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $950,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $750,000, 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
balance of the TA costs, amounting to $200,000 equivalent, will be met by the Government in kind: 
office accommodations, counterpart staff support, facilities for seminars and  meetings, other

5
administrative expenses, and part of local transport costs. The Government has been informed 
that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. A tentative cost 
table is in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  MARD  will  act  as  Executing  Agency  for  TA  implementation.  MARD  has  extensive 
experience in administering externally funded projects in Viet Nam. An interdepartmental project 
preparation  group  of  MARD,  comprising  technical  personnel  designated  by  the  relevant 
departments, will be established to act as the direct counterpart group for the TA, provide policy 
and  technical  guidance,  and  facilitate  resolution  of  outstanding  TA  implementation  issues. 
Representatives  of  key  potential  provinces  will  be  invited  as  required.  MARD,  through  its 
International Cooperation Department, will also ensure  central-level interministerial coordination 
with the relevant agencies of the Government, including the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of 
Industry, Ministry of Planning and Investment, Ministry of Public Health, Ministry of Science and 
Technology,  Ministry of Trade, and  State Bank of Viet Nam. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 8 months, August 2007– March 2008. It will provide 70 
person-months of consulting services, comprising 28 person-months of international and 42 
person-months  of  national  expertise  in  agricultural  economics,  agronomy,  postharvest 
operations, SME credit, institutional development, agricultural marketing, financial and economic 
analyses,  social  development,  and  environmental  and  public  health  assessment.  The 
international agricultural economist will lead the TA consultant team. An international consulting 
firm will provide all the international and national consulting services. The consultants will be 
engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). The quality- and cost-based selection method will be used, and the 
shortlisted firms will present simplified technical proposals. The consultant will purchase the 
necessary  office  equipment  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). Equipment procured will be handed over to the Government at TA 
completion. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
18.  The TA will organize stakeholder workshops to disseminate outputs, obtain feedback 
and views, refine the project proposal, and ensure close liaison with key stakeholders at the 
national, regional, and provincial levels as appropriate. Tripartite review meetings involving the 
Government, the TA consultant team, and ADB will be organized at least three times at critical 
milestone events. The consultant will prepare (i) a TA inception report, including a detailed work 
program, to be submitted within 3 weeks of the start of the TA and to be discussed at the initial 
tripartite review meeting; (ii) an interim report to present preliminary findings, to be submitted by 
the end of the fourth month of the TA and to be discussed at the interim tripartite review meeting; 
(iii)  a  draft  final  report  about  1  month  before  TA  completion  and  to  be  discussed  at  
 national- and regional-level workshops and at the final tripartite review meeting; and (iv) a final 
report upon TA completion. At least 15 copies of each report will be provided to the Government. 
Key outputs of the TA will be translated into Vietnamese as required. The TA review missions of 
ADB will coincide with the tripartite review meetings.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for preparing the Quality and Safety Improvement of Agricultural 
Products Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Viet Nam: 
In Viet Nam, the agriculture sector accounts for about 21% of the country’s gross domestic product, and 
about 57% of the labor force. The sector’s shares are expected to decrease due to the relatively more 
rapid growth of the industry and service sectors. However, agriculture will continue to play an important 
economic  role  in  achieving  sustainable  and  equitable  growth  and  in  reducing  rural  poverty.  The 
Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS), which is the Government’s long-term 
strategy for poverty reduction, emphasizes the importance of agriculture and rural development in poverty 
reduction, particularly in upland and remote areas. This strategic thrust of CPRGS is clearly reflected in 
the 5-year Socio-Economic Development Plan (2006-2010) launched in June 2006. The ensuing loan 
project will contribute to achieving the poverty reduction objectives of the Government’s strategy and plan. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis         Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
A detailed analysis is required of the social and poverty impact of the ensuing loan project on the potential 
project beneficiaries in accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) relevant guidelines and 
standard practices.  The analysis  should  include socioeconomic  profiles  of  potential  beneficiaries  by 
income and poverty levels, gender, ethnicity, and other factors as baseline information; and assess their 
roles, needs, and absorptive capacity in relation to the ensuing loan project. Available studies and reports 
on the poverty situation in Viet Nam will be reviewed and complemented by participatory rural appraisals 
to be carried out in the potential project provinces. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
A stakeholder analysis will be carried out under the technical assistance (TA). A series of national and provincial 
stakeholder consultations will be conducted at critical milestones during TA implementation. In consultation 
with the TA executing agency, the TA will ensure participation of the relevant government agencies, 
provincial governments, farmer groups, other external funding agencies, private enterprises, and civil 
society organizations. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
A specific strategy for stakeholder participation will be worked out at TA inception as part of the TA work program. 
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
In accordance with the Government’s approved strategies and stated commitments, the ensuing loan project will 
incorporate specific measures or an action plan to ensure gender equality in the proposed project outputs.

12  Appendix 4 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General Work Requirements 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  the  following  consulting  services.  The 
international agricultural economist will lead the consultant team. The consultants should have 
adequate working experience in Southeast Asia, preferably in Viet  Nam. The international 
consultants should have (i) adequate relevant working experience in preparing projects for 
multilateral  financial  institutions  in  Southeast  Asia,  (ii)  sound  knowledge  of  and  practical 
experience  in  relevant  fields,  and  (iii)  strong  interpersonal  and  communication  skills.  The 
national consultants should (i) have extensive knowledge and experience in the relevant fields 
in Viet Nam, (ii) have experience in working with government institutions and international 
consultants, and (iii) be fluent in written and spoken English.  
 
Consultant Expertise and Person-Months

B.  Specific Work Assignments for Consultants 
 
  1.  Agricultural Economist/Team Leader 
 
2.  The consultant will 
(i)  assess the overall macroeconomic situation and development contexts in Viet 
Nam, including a review of key structural changes, market development, and 
rural-urban transition; 
(ii)  review the Government’s development plans, policies, and strategies; and the 
country strategies and programs of ADB and other external funding agencies; 
(iii)  conduct an in-depth assessment of the agriculture sector, including the latest 
data on production, yield, farming systems, and resource potentials; 
(iv)  assess marketing of agricultural and agro-based products, including forward and 
backward linkages; and analyze market trends, price movements, and projected 
demand for Vietnamese products; 
(v)  examine the key opportunities and issues related to quality improvements and 
food  safety  of  agricultural  and  agro-based  products,  including  relevant 
Government  policies  and  regulations,  by  drawing  lessons  from  national  and 
international experiences, where appropriate;

Appendix 4           13 
(vi)  assess investment opportunities for and constraints to private agribusinesses in 
Viet  Nam,  taking  into  consideration  access  to  markets,  and  market-related 
infrastructure; 
(vii)  examine past, ongoing, and planned loan and TA projects in agriculture  financed 
by ADB, other external funding agencies, and civil society organizations; identify 
important lessons from similar projects and programs in Viet Nam; 
(viii)  initiate a logical framework for the ensuing loan project and analyze relevant 
sectors and subsectors;  
(ix)  lead the TA consultant team in formulating the detailed project design, which 
should be simple and realistic; 
(x)  assist in preparing Government feasibility studies and Procurement Plan for the 
ensuing loan project; and  
(xi)  ensure that all aspects of the ensuing loan project are assessed in terms of its 
technical, environmental, social, financial, and economic viability. 
 
  2.  Agronomists    
 
3.  The consultant will 
(i)  assess soil, climatic, and topographic conditions of the potential project provinces 
for  the  ensuing  loan  project,  and  identify  important  crops    for  commercial 
production, marketing, and processing; 
(ii)  examine area-specific agronomic requirements for soil treatment, integrated pest 
management, planting, grafting, harvesting, storing, packing, and transportation; 
(iii)  identify main causes of low productivity and low product quality of commercial 
crops, and recommend effective measures to address the problems;  
(iv)  highlight major problems related to inappropriate use of pesticides, herbicides, 
and other chemicals; and evaluate alternative options for improving food safety; 
(v)  assess existing institutional arrangements for implementing and disseminating 
domestically  and  internationally  recognized  good  agricultural  practices  for 
commercial crops;  
(vi)  assess the current situation of seed and seedling production, and recommend 
effective measures for improving the availability of planting materials suitable for 
commercial sale and processing; and 
(vii)  present typical cropping patterns and budgets for the selected crops. 
 
  3.  Postharvest Operations Specialists 
 
4.  The specialist will 
(i)  conduct a detailed assessment of the opportunities and constraints related to 
agricultural postharvest operations in Viet Nam; 
(ii)  assess the capacity and limitation of the existing agricultural research, extension, 
and market information systems, with emphasis on postharvest research, and 
product  grading  and  certification;  and  recommend  appropriate  measures  for 
enhancing institutional capacity and resources of these systems; 
(iii)  examine ongoing and planned competitive grant systems for agricultural post-
harvest research, and existing systems for integrated research and extension 
being carried out at selected regional research institutes and centers; 
(iv)  review  existing  linkages  between  national  and  regional  agricultural  research 
institutes,  and  extension  services  for  commercial  crop  production  and  post-
harvest operations; and incorporate into the project design appropriate measures 
to strengthen operational linkages between postharvest research and extension;

14  Appendix 4 
(v)  examine the feasibility of strengthening SME-assisted postharvest operations 
through the establishment of enterprise innovation funds for supporting market-
driven product development; and 
(vi)  assess the existing capacity of public extension services for commercial crop 
production and marketing, and product storing, processing and packaging; and 
recommend measures to strengthen the capacity of grassroot-level agricultural 
extension services to improve the quality and safety of agricultural and agro-
based products. 
 
  4.  SME Credit Specialists 
 
5.  The specialists will 
(i)  conduct an analytical review of the financial sector in Viet Nam, with emphasis on 
(a) the availability of and gaps in medium- to long-term funds for lending to 
private  agribusiness  households  and  agro-based  SMEs,  (b)  financial 
intermediaries involved in SME lending operations and their operational issues, 
and (c) progress of reform measures being carried out in the financial sector; 
(ii)  identify  financial  intermediaries  for  possible  participation  in  the  ensuing  loan 
project based on a detailed assessment of their performance, capability, and 
geographical coverage; 
(iii)  establish appropriate eligibility criteria for selecting  borrowers of SME credit 
funds; 
(iv)  estimate costs involved in SME lending operations, including administrative costs 
and loan loss provisions, and propose appropriate relending and onlending terms 
and conditions; and 
(v)  project the aggregate amount of SME credit funds that the ensuing loan project 
will need. 
 
  5.  Institutional Development Specialists 
 
6.  The specialists will 
(i)  assess the systems, laws, and regulations for standardizing quality and safety for 
agricultural and agro-based products in Viet Nam; and recommend measures for 
improvements to meet market requirements; 
(ii)  review laws, regulations, and practices covering agricultural product cooperatives 
and  farmers’  collaborative  groups;  and  formulate  appropriate  measures  to 
strengthen them; 
(iii)  examine  the  performance  and  capacity  of  the  staff  and  other  stakeholders 
involved  in  agribusiness  development,  and  agricultural  support  services  at 
provincial, district and commune levels; and assess the need for upgrading and 
developing human resources; and 
(iv)  examine the need for building the capacity of relevant institutions involved in  
implementing the national action plans for hygiene and food safety of agricultural 
and agro-based products. 
 
  6.  Agricultural Marketing Specialists 
 
7.  The specialists will 
(i)  review the supply chains of agricultural and agro-based products; and identify 
key constraints to effective market transactions;

Appendix 4           15 
(ii)  examine key constraints to private agribusinesses, including issues related to 
marketing, certification, and private property rights; 
(iii)  assess the availability of and need for supportive market infrastructure in the 
potential project provinces and major market centers, and propose measures for 
reducing marketing costs, and improving product quality and safety; 
(iv)  review existing market information and intelligence systems, and recommend 
specific measures to improve them for more effective use and dissemination of 
accurate and updated market information; and 
(v)  assess the performance, capacity, and bargaining powers of farmers for effective 
marketing  of  agricultural  and  agro-based  products  in  the  potential  project 
provinces;  and  recommend  specific  measures  to  improve  their  marketing 
capacity. 
 
  7.  Financial and Economic Analyses Specialists 
 
8.  The specialists will 
(i)  prepare the detailed cost estimates of the ensuing loan project following ADB 
standard  practices;  and  propose  appropriate  financing  plans  and  fund  flow 
arrangements satisfactory to the Government and ADB; 
(ii)  carry  out  financial  and  economic  analyses  for  the  ensuing  loan  project,  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects;  
(iii)  present typical income and expenditure patterns of farm households with various 
cropping patterns and landholdings in the potential project provinces; and 
(iv)  identify  possible  risks  to  the  project’s  effectiveness  and  sustainability;  and 
recommend appropriate measures for minimizing them; and. 
(v)  undertake  a  financial  management  assessment  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on Financial Management and Analysis of Projects  (2005).  
   
  8.  Social Development Specialists 
 
9.  The specialists will 
(i)  conduct a detailed social and poverty analysis, including assessments of social 
safeguards  related  to  the  ensuing  loan  project,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Handbook for Poverty and Social Analysis (2001), Handbook for Incorporation of 
Social Dimensions in Projects (1994), Gender Checklist in Agriculture, Policy on 
Indigenous  Peoples  (1998),  and  other  relevant  ADB  social  policies  and 
guidelines;  
(ii)  examine  detailed  socioeconomic  profiles  of  potential  beneficiaries  in  the 
proposed project provinces by income and poverty levels, gender, ethnicity, and 
other factors; and assess their roles, needs, and absorptive capacity in relation to 
the ensuing loan project; 
(iii)  assess the current issues related to gender, ethnic minority groups, rural poverty, 
and impact of food safety issues on the poor in the potential project provinces; 
and examine any possible project impact on gender, ethnic minorities, and the 
rural poor; 
(iv)  formulate action plans to mainstream the issues in (iii), including an indigenous 
peoples development plan and a gender action plan for the ensuing loan project, 
when any significant  impact on gender and ethnic minority groups is anticipated; 
and 
(v)  establish benchmark information related to gender, ethnic minority groups, and 
rural poverty; and design an appropriate system for monitoring and evaluation.

16  Appendix 4 
 
9.  Environmental and Public Health Assessment Specialists 
 
10.  The specialists will 
(i)  examine potential environmental and public health issues related to occupational 
health risks, food safety, and possible hazardous wastes and by-products from 
processing factories; 
(ii)  provide a detailed overview and assessment of public health institutions and 
regulations  related  to  food  safety;  and  recommend  measures  for  improving 
relevant institutional linkages;   
(iii)  assess potential environmental impacts including cumulative and indirect impacts 
associated  with  the  proposed  project  interventions;  and  prepare  an  initial 
environmental examination (IEE) report and a summary IEE for the project in 
accordance with ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003), and the 
Government’s environmental regulations; 
(iv)  identify training needs to enhance environmental benefits or minimize the likely 
adverse impact of the ensuing loan project on the environment and public health;  
(v)  assess  the  potential  environmental  impact  of  sample  subprojects  to  be 
considered under credit lines for agro-based SMEs in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Environmental Assessment of Financial Intermediation Loans and 
Equity Investments; 
(vi)  assess the existing and proposed environmental assessment and management 
systems  and  capacity  of  the  project  executing  agency  and  the  participating 
financial intermediaries; and 
(vii)  identify  medium-  to  long-term  environmental  and  public  health  concerns  in 
agriculture and agribusiness with reference to ADB’s draft Country Environmental 
Analysis for Viet Nam (2006).9 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
9  ADB. (2006). Country Environmental Analysis for Viet Nam. Manila
